desc.size: Annual or biennial herb, 20 cm - 0.7 m tall, erect.

part.partText: usually multiple, from a stout taproot, branching above, dense hairy-glandular (some of the hairs branched).

alternate, one to three times pinnately divided, stalkless, to 15 cm long, to 7 cm wide, becoming smaller upward and less dissected, oblong, hairy-glandular (some of the hairs branched). Leafstalks grooved above.

in a loose, branched cluster (raceme), which is borne terminally on a stem. Racemes to 30 cm long, hairy-glandular. Sepals four, egg-shaped. Petals four, yellow, small (flowers 2 - 4 mm wide), slightly recurved. Stamens six.
a pod (silique), erect or ascending, widely spreading, 6 mm - 1.3 cm long, 1 - 2 mm wide, three to eight times as long, club-shaped. Seeds in two rows in each chamber.

similarSpecies.comments: Descurainia sophia is similar but has longer pods, densely whitish-hairy (not hairy-glandular) stems, and leaves which are slightly more divided.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Occurs on limestone and sandstone cliffs, but frequently found along railroads. It has also been found growing as a roadside weed and a weed of sandy cultivated ground. Look for it in dry, open or sparsely wooded areas as well.

notes.comments: Apparently introduced into the Chicago Region from farther west.

etymology.comments: Descurainia is named after the 18th Century French botanist and physician Francois Descourain (1658-1740). Pinnata means feather-shaped.
